title: Elizaveta Semenova
text:
Elizaveta (Liza) Semenova is a lecturer in Biostatistics, Computational Epidemiology, and Machine Learning at the School of Public Health, and a Schmidt Sciences AI2050 Early Career Fellow. Her research focuses on scalable methods for spatiotemporal statistics and Bayesian machine learning in epidemiology, including deep generative models to enhance MCMC inference in spatial and disease transmission modelling. Looking ahead, she looks to broaden research portfolio by broadening the application of deep learning surrogates.


 Back to top

title: Sen Wang
text:
Sen Wang is a Senior Lecturer at the Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering and I-X. His research sits at the intersection of robotics, computer vision and machine learning, driving robots to understand and operate autonomously in unstructured, dynamic environments through probabilistic and learning approaches.


 Back to top

title: Fadil Bidmos
text:
Fadil Bidmos is a MRC Senior (Non-Clinical) Fellow and Proleptic Senior Lecturer in Bacterial Vaccinology in the Department of Infectious Disease. His research programme focusses on designing and developing next-generation vaccines for bacterial meningitis and AMR threats He has an interest in application of ML approaches to therapeutic antibody and vaccine antigen discovery.


 Back to top

title: Yang Guang
text:
Dr. Guang Yang is an Associate Professor in the Department of Bioengineering and Imperial-X at Imperial College London. His research focuses on developing AI-based techniques for medical image analysis and healthcare applications.


 Back to top

title: Falah Rahim
text:
I am an Al/XR specialist, who holds an M.S. in Electrical-Electronics and Telecommunications from the University Technology Malaysia, Malaysia, and a Ph.D. in Electrical and Computer Engineering from the University of Lisbon, Portugal. Currently, I am a visiting researcher at Imperial College London, focusing on developing Al models for digital pathology.


 Back to top

title: Kelly Zhang
text:
Kelly Zhang is a Lecturer in statistics and I-X. She has a background in designing decision-making algorithms and collaborating with people in digital health.


 Back to top

title: Ana Espinosa Gonzalez
text:
Ana Espinosa is a general practitioner and research associate at the School of Public Health. She is also working as research manager for the Northwest London Integrated Care Board Health Equity programme. She has a background on health systems and policy, health service research and is interested in the use of AI tools to support healthcare management decision making. Rachel Christie is the Senior Population Data analytics at the NWL Integrated Care Board. She has a background in public health and is interested in developing risk stratification and prediction tools to support ICB decisions.


 Back to top

title: Jiansheng Xiang
text:
Dr Jiansheng Xiang is a research fellow in Computational Mechanics. Jiansheng has a great passion for research in applied mathematics and modelling and has continuously diversified his efforts to numerous fields of engineering mathematics and its application areas: computational fluid/solid mechanics, fluid-solid interactions, heat transfer, fracture mechanics, and turbulent flow.


 Back to top

title: Mahdi Moradi Marjaneh
text:
I am an Advanced Research Fellow in Bioinformatics and Precision Medicine, working closely with the Virology as well as Pediatrics Infectious Disease sections in the Department of Infectious Disease. With a background in clinical medicine and extensive experience in bioinformatics, I have an interest in applying AI to precision medicine.


 Back to top

title: Dandan Zhang
text:
Dandan Zhang is a Lecturer at Imperial-X and the Department of Bioengineering. Her research interests lie at the intersection of robotics and AI, with a focus on healthcare applications.


 Back to top

title: Margherita Molaro
text:
Margherita Molaro is a research fellow in the School of Public Health. She works on health-system modelling and resource allocation questions using the Thanzi La Onse model (www.tlomodel.org) and has a background in computational astrophysics.


 Back to top

title: Hamed Haddadi
text:
Hamed Haddadi is a Reader in Human-Centred Systems at the Dyson School of Design Engineering, Imperial College London. His research focuses on user-centric systems, privacy, and applied machine learning.


 Back to top

title: Beatriz Galindo Prieto
text:
Beatriz Galindo-Prieto is a research associate with an integrated MSc 5-years degree in Chemistry at the University of the Balearic Islands (Spain), and a PhD at Umea University (Sweden) in Chemometrics/Chemistry focused on machine learning algorithm development (especially related to partial least squares methods and variable influence on projection) and its applications in natural and medical sciences, as well as industry. She worked as research fellow (with her own funded 1-year fellowship, ERCIM) at the Department of Engineering Cybernetics of NTNU (Norway), and as research associate at Weill Cornell Medicine (Alzheimer’s and omics data analysis) and at IDE and ERG of School of Public Health of Imperial College London, where she is interested on AI approaches for Environmental Health.


 Back to top

title: Gina Brown
text:
Professor Gina Brown is a Consultant Radiologist and Professor of Gastrointestinal Cancer Imaging at Imperial College. Over her career, she has made significant contributions to the field of colorectal cancer Professor Brown’s work has been recognized globally, and she has contributed to several guidelines and initiatives aimed at improving cancer care


 Back to top

title: Frederick Wai Keung Tam
text:
Frederick Tam is the Ken and Mary Minton Chair of Renal Medicine. He has been investigating the importance of cytokines in pathogenesis of kidney diseases.. The expertise of his research group has been applied in the preclinical and early clinical development of anti-inflammatory therapies, in collaboration with the industry. He has been collaborating with Imperial College Health Partners (ICHP) and Institute of Global Health Innovation (IGHI) to improve early diagnosis and personalised treatment of kidney diseases.


 Back to top

title: Charlie Whittaker
text:
Dr. Charles Whittaker is a Sir Henry Wellcome Research Fellow and incoming Assistant Professor of Infectious Diseases and Vaccinology at Berkeley Public Health where his work focuses on the dynamics, detectability and control of pathogens with pandemic potential. His work uses viral phylodynamics and epidemiological modelling to uncover new insights into how pathogens spread through populations and to enhance preparedness and response strategies for public health emergencies.


 Back to top

title: Christopher Pain
text:
Christopher Pain is a computational physicist who is head of the Applied Modelling and Computation Group in the Department of Earth Science and Engineering, as well as head of the Data Assimilation lab in the DSI and a co-director of the Imperial-X initiative “Centre for AI-Physics Modelling”. He has a background in numerical methods, computational fluid dynamics, AI, data assimilation and optimisation problems, and currently works on problems in health and the environment, and geothermal, wind and nuclear energy.


 Back to top

title: Kris Parag
text:
Kris is an advanced research fellow with a engineering background and experience in infectious disease modelling. He is interested in better using statistical and machine learning to improve how real-time decisions are made in the face of uncertain data.


 Back to top

title: Thomas Beaney
text:
Thomas Beaney is a GP and Clinical Research at The George Institute for Global Health. He has a background in epidemiology and during his recent PhD, developed AI methods for learning patterns of chronic conditions using electronic health record data.


 Back to top

title: Brendan Delaney
text:
Professor Brendan Delaney is Chair in Medical Informatics at Imperial College London, specialising in the Learning Health System concept, AI in healthcare, and clinical informatics. His research focuses on applied AI, explainable AI for healthcare, and improving diagnostic pathways.


 Back to top

title: OJ Watson
text:
Oliver Watson is a lecturer and Schmidt AI in science fellow in the School of Public Health. He has with a background in infectious disease modelling in malaria and COVID-19, and an interest in applying AI methods for pandemic preparedness.


 Back to top

title: Collaborative Workshop on AI in Medicine
text:
18 February 2025, I-X
The “Collaborative Workshop on AI in Medicine” is a half-day event bringing together researchers, clinicians, data scientists, and AI experts from across Imperial College London to explore innovative applications of AI in medicine. The event aims to foster interdisciplinary collaborations and catalyse future funding opportunities for AI-driven healthcare research.
To facilitate these connections, this workshop provides a space for Imperial researchers from diverse disciplines to share expertise, identify synergies, and initiate new collaborations that can lead to innovative research and funding proposals.

title: Collaborative Workshop on AI in Medicine
text:
Workshop Schedule

Welcome & Introductions (2:30 – 2:45 PM)
Who’s in the Room? (2:45 – 3:00 PM)
Breakout Working Groups (3:00 – 4:00 PM)
Group Sharing & Discussion (4:00 – 4:30 PM)
Facilitated Networking (4:30 – 5:15 PM)
Closing Remarks (5:15 – 5:30 PM)
Networking Reception (5:30 PM onwards)

title: Collaborative Workshop on AI in Medicine
text:
Venue
The workshop will take place at:

Date: Tuesday 18 March. 2:30pm - 5:30pm
Location:

LRT 608A+B, I-X, 6th Floor I-HUB (Translation & Innovation Hub)
Imperial College White City Campus
84 Wood Lane
London
W12 0BZ
Location Map

How to Reach the Event:

Directions to the White City Campus
On arrival at the I-Hub, reception will give you access to the lifts to reach the 6th floor. Please follow signs to LRT 608A+B

Welcome & Introductions (2:30 – 2:45 PM)

Opening remarks and workshop objectives.
Overview of AI in medicine and interdisciplinary collaboration.

Who’s in the Room? (2:45 – 3:00 PM)

Participant introductions to highlight expertise and shared interests.
Icebreaker activity to encourage engagement.

Breakout Working Groups (3:00 – 4:00 PM)

Participants form groups based on shared interests.
Internal 1-minute presentations on research background and project ideas.
Brainstorming sessions to identify potential research collaborations and funding opportunities.

Group Sharing & Discussion (4:00 – 4:30 PM)

Groups share key insights and proposed collaborations.
Facilitated discussion to identify common themes and cross-group synergies.

Facilitated Networking (4:30 – 5:15 PM)

Participants connect based on shared interests.
Open discussions to explore potential interdisciplinary projects.

Closing Remarks (5:15 – 5:30 PM)

Summary of key insights and next steps.
Opportunities for ongoing collaboration.

Networking Reception (5:30 PM onwards)

Informal discussions over drinks and refreshments.
Further opportunity to build collaborations in a relaxed setting.

title: Alejandra Tomas
text:
Alejandra Tomas is a Reader in Cell Biology and Head of Section of Cell Biology and Functional Genomics at the Dept. of Metabolism, Digestion and Reproduction. Her research is focused on the study of the spatiotemporal regulation of signalling and mechanisms of signal compartmentalisation of the glucagon receptor family in pancreatic islets and other metabolically relevant cell types (hepatocytes, adipocytes, etc.), for the control of blood glucose levels and related metabolic parameters, with direct application to the development of novel type 2 diabetes (T2D), obesity, and metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) therapies.


 Back to top

title: Reham Aldakhil
text:
Reham Aldakhil is a PhD student in the Global Digital Health Unit at School of Public Health, with over 10 years of clinical and digital health experience, combining expertise in pharmacy practice and health informatics. Her current research focuses on investigating the impact of virtual consultations on healthcare delivery and patient outcomes, with particular interest in applying machine learning models to optimise healthcare service utilization and improve patient engagement in type 2 diabetes care.


 Back to top

title: Oshini Shivakumar
text:
Oshini Shivakumar is a Renal Trainee with an interest in dialysis care and research. She is currently pursuing a PhD to study individuals returning to dialysis after kidney transplant failure- mortality risk and patient experience. This project is in collaboration with the Renal Research Institute, New York. She is one of the Registrar representatives of the UK Kidney Associations’ Kidney Quality Improvement Project looking at patients with Advanced Kidney. She is interested in learning and advancing AI in renal medicine, including dietetic advice for individuals on dialysis in a mult-ethnic population such as West London.


 Back to top

title: Sherwin Varghese
text:
Sherwin Varghese is a research assistant within the Safe AI Labs (SAIL) led by Prof. Alessio Lomuscio at the Department of Computing, Imperial College London. Additionally, he is a UKRI funded Ph.D. student in the Department of Computing. His current research focuses on improving the robustness of temporal AI systems - specifically, techniques to improve the scalability of formal verification for video based systems.


 Back to top

title: Mary Brenda Akoda
text:
Mary-Brenda Akoda is a Google DeepMind Scholar and Master of Research (MRes) student in AI & ML, currently working at I-X on novel deep generative models for accelerated MRI reconstruction. With a diverse background spanning AI, software engineering, and entrepreneurship, her experience includes a patent in AI for Ophthalmology, pioneering contributions across three teams at Microsoft—including at the Microsoft MR/AI Research Lab in Cambridge—and co-founding a Mastercard‑backed Edtech startup for African languages preservation. She also mentors underrepresented youth in AI and software engineering, and her Udemy ChatGPT Masterclass is rated in the top 3% of courses.


 Back to top

title: Becca Asquith
text:
Becca Asquith is a professor in Mathematical Immunology. She is trained in mathematics and theoretical particle physics (to PhD level) but now works in human immunology. She has expertise in using both mechanistic and data-driven modelling approaches to study human adaptive immunity and immune cell dynamics.


 Back to top

title: Ahmed Alboksmaty
text:
Ahmed Alboksmaty is a Clinical Research Fellow and PhD Candidate at the Institute of Global Health Innovation, Department of Surgery and Cancer, Imperial College London. I have 6+ years of experience working in health policy for quality and patient safety with the United Nations, mainly WHO, in addition to two years as an Academic Clinical Fellow at the University of Cambridge in the same field and two extra years as a Research Associate with the Department of Primary Care and Public Health at Imperial College (2020-2022). I am also a GP Registrar with a special interest in digital health technologies in primary care.


 Back to top

title: Tricia Tay
text:
Tricia is a Clinical Research Fellow and second year PhD student in the Institute of Global Health Innovation. She has background in surgery and clinical education. She has an interest in improving care of older adults.


 Back to top

title: Gareth Jones
text:
Gareth Jones is a senior clinical lecturer and consultant knee surgeon at Imperial College. He has a background in optimising the treatment of knee osteoarthritis, with a number of publications exploring the use of AI to triage patients and predict osteoarthritis progression, determine surgical treatment options, and analyse outcomes.


 Back to top

title: Anuja Mitra
text:
Anuja Mitra is an MRC Clinical Research Fellow and an upper GI surgeon by background. She completed her PhD, funded by the Royal College of Surgeons, MRC, and NIHR, investigating metabolomics and early biomarker detection to enhance patient outcomes in oesophago-gastric cancer. Her current research focuses on advancing surgical safety, quality, and outcomes through intra-operative video analysis and AI-driven innovations.


 Back to top

title: Ollie Jones
text:
I am a BHF Clinical Research Fellow in Cardiology. I have paused my clinical work to undertake a PhD Hammersmith Hospital. This involves collecting electrical data in cath labs and mapping the patterns of activity algorithmically.


 Back to top

title: Juan Delgado
text:
Juan Delgado is a post-doctoral researcher at the NHLI (faculty of Medicine). He has a background in mathematical biology in multiple disease areas within drug discovery.


 Back to top

title: Mayur Murali
text:
Mayur Murali is an anaesthesia and intensive care medicine registrar and PhD candidate in the Faculty of Medicine at Imperial College London. He has an interest in applying AI methods to understand critical care ventilation data.


 Back to top

title: Fan Chung
text:
Professor of respiratory Medicine and Clinician. respiratory disease mechanisms and pohenotyping. Effect of air pollution.


 Back to top

title: Manolo Perez
text:
Manolo Perez is a Schmidt AI in science fellow in Life Sciences. His background is on population genetics and evolution. He has been applying AI models to evolutionary biology models recently, with a focus on viral phylogenies.


 Back to top

title: Suveer Singh
text:
Suveer Singh is Professor of Practice in Respiratory and Intensive Care at Imperial College-Royal Brompton and Chelsea&Westminster Hospitals. He has a background in educational training and bronchoscopy research. More recently developing better standards for training in bronchoscopy using novel technologies including AI


 Back to top

title: Sofia Yaliraki
text:
Sofia Yaliraki is a Professor of Theoretical Chemistry in the Department of Chemistry at Imperial College London. Her research interests include the development of theoretical and computational methodologies for complex molecular systems.


 Back to top

title: Weihua Zhang
text:
Weihua Zhang is a bioinformatician in the School of Public Health. She has a background in Genetic Epidemiology / Statistical Genetics / Epidemiology, and is interested in applying AI methods to large biobank and omics studies to identify risk factors for disease predicative models and future prevention of diseases.


 Back to top

title: Dennis Wang
text:
Dennis Wang is a chair in data science at National Heart and Lung Institute and senior principal scientist at A*STAR in Singapore. He applies machine learning approaches to help diagnose and develop treatments for complex conditions (e.g. pulmonary hypertension, dementia, metabolic syndrome) across the human lifespan (child to elderly).


 Back to top

title: Jane Hirst
text:
Jane Hirst is an academic obstetrician and Chair of Global Women’s Health, Imperial and Program Director for the Women’s Health Program at the George Institute for Global Health. She has expertise in pregnancy complications, digital and mHealth solutions, climate change and women’s health and is developing a program around how AI can improve women’s access to quality healthcare globally.


 Back to top

title: Daniel Elson
text:
Daniel Elson is Professor in the Hamlyn Centre for Robotic Surgery, Department of Surgery and Cancer and the Institute of Global Health Innovation. His group develops and clinically translates optical and photonics technologies for surgical endoscopic sensing and imaging applications, to provide minimally-invasive diagnostic guidance and to characterise different disease states during intervention. Current technologies under investigation include multispectral, polarization-resolved and fluorescence sensing/imaging, supported by computer vision and robotic guidance techniques.


 Back to top
